etymologies: late Middle English: from medieval Latin crucibulum ‘night lamp, crucible’ (perhaps originally a lamp hanging in front of a crucifix), from Latin crux, cruc- ‘cross’

definitions: a ceramic or metal container in which metals or other substances may be melted or subjected to very high temperatures

examples.text: the crucible tipped and the mold filled with liquid metal

shortDefinitions: ceramic or metal container in which metals or other substances may be melted or subjected to very high temperatures

definitions: a situation of severe trial, or in which different elements interact, leading to the creation of something new

examples.text: their relationship was forged in the crucible of war

shortDefinitions: situation of severe trial, or in which different elements interact
